comment.body:
On more thought, this concerns the above `pl.Load()` call as well, since it enables `onBufferOpen`, `onBufPaneOne` etc, which are global.

This seems be a problem with the very concept of enabling/disabling plugins per buffer, not just with its implementation in this PR. If a plugin is disabled globally (and thus not loaded yet), and we enable it locally for a given buffer, we need to load this plugin, to make it work for this buffer. But by loading it we actually enable it globally for other buffers as well (although only partially, but that's even worse).

I think jumping to the beginning of a line is a more common use case (for example, think of jumping to a line specified in a compiler error message). Your use case seems to be quite specific. For instance, am I right that your use case assumes that there are no tab characters in the file, or if there are, they are all at the same positions in each line (so that when moving to another line, if the logical column number doesn't change, the visual column location doesn't change either)?

By the way... I've just realized that relative column numbers might not make a lot of sense either, for similar reasons. Are there real uses for relative column numbers? If not, maybe for simplicity it's better to stick to relative line numbers only? I.e. support `+`, `-` and `~` for lines only, and for columns support only specifying either absolute column, or no column at all (i.e. don't extend the existing functionality for column numbers). @dase78 what do you think?

issue.title: How to define a file format?
Editor gets angry with C++ in Header files.
issue.body:
I have been using version 2.0.10 to write C++ for about a year and noticed that the syntax highlighting for the headerfiles (*.h) was off, but didn't mind too much. Recently, I noticed that this version of the editor seems to default to Objective-C for header files, so I set it to C++, which fixed the highlighting, but instead started complaining about the code when saving the document. Since this code was legal and compiled without any warnings or notes from the compiler (g++ of GCC), I assumed it was a bug and updated the editor to 2.0.12.
Now, the editor not only gets angry when filetype is set to 'c++', but saving with the default/assumed filetype (which is 'c' with this version) also makes it complain. This did not happen previously.

2.0.10: If default is Objective-C, it does not get angry when saving, but if set explicitly it would be. If default is C, it would be.
2.0.12: The default is now C, and it gets angry by default.

When filetype is set to 'c++', which is what I want to do, commenting out and moving code makes it upset with different things, and it will even remember the line it used to get angry with, even if the code is removed and the file is saved.
![micro_cpp_h_issue_001](https://github.com/zyedidia/micro/assets/60481758/8a3dd8aa-e05f-42e9-b7a3-7ce1a5834c73)

 This is only an issue with C++ code in *.h-files, *.cpp-files do not upset the editor.

OS: Zorin OS 16.1
Terminal: GNOME Terminal 3.36.2

issue.title: cannot add comments to bindings.json, it's rewritten and comments are removed
issue.body:
I'm experimenting with `bindings.json` trying to find the best hotkeys that work for me. It means, I often want to put something in comments, but I want to leave them because I might re-enable them again. My `bindings.json` looks like this:

```json
{
    "\u001b[47;5u": "lua:comment.comment,CursorDown",  // Ctrl-/ , toggle comment
    // "Alt-/": "lua:comment.comment",
    // "Alt-h": "ToggleHelp",
    "Ctrl-t": "command:vsplit,command:term",
    "Ctrl-g": "command-edit:goto ",
    "Ctrl-r": "command-edit:replace ",
    // "CtrlUnderscore": "lua:comment.comment",
    "OldBackspace": "command-edit:replace -l "
}
```

However, when I save it, quit micro and re-open it, it's modified automatically to look like this:

```json
{
    "\u001b[47;5u": "lua:comment.comment,CursorDown",
    "Alt-/": "lua:comment.comment",
    "Ctrl-g": "command-edit:goto ",
    "Ctrl-r": "command-edit:replace ",
    "Ctrl-t": "command:vsplit,command:term",
    "CtrlUnderscore": "lua:comment.comment",
    "OldBackspace": "command-edit:replace -l "
}
```

Why is it happening and how to avoid this? micro shouldn't modify the settings files or at least there should be an option to tell micro to treat these files in read-only mode. If I want to modify them, I'll do that manually.

In addition, it seems that  "Alt-/" and "CtrlUnderscore" cannot be removed, it's always written back.

comment.body: Thanks. This is a strange behavior, but OK, I can live with that.
